Objection: Since adequate support has not been provided for the director to determine if the filing meets the requirements of AS 21.39, the waiting period in AS 21.39.220(b) has not commenced and the proposed effective date may not comply with the waiting period requirement. If necessary, a new effective date must be requested in your response, which must again allow for at least a 30-day waiting period following its receipt by the division. The response must identify any changes to the filing; see 3 AAC 31.210(p).  If the revisions have impacted the rate level impacts required to be reported in the transmittal document per 3 AAC 31.225(c)(2) and (3), the revised impacts must be provided as required by 3 AAC 31.225(e). If neither a response nor a written request for a 15-day extension is received within 30 days from the date of this letter, the division will disapprove the filing and the filing shall not become effective.  A response received after the expiration of the response period must be a complete resubmission of the filing, which specifically addresses the above questions and comments and references the tracking number; 3 AAC 31.210(i).  The response must be received before 3:00pm Alaska time (6:00pm Central) on the due date. If a response is received after 3:00 pm Alaska time (6:00 pm Central) or on a weekend or state holiday, the receipt date is the next working day as required by 3 AAC 31.205(b).  Therefore, when the due date falls on a weekend or state holiday, the response must be submitted no later than 3:00pm on Friday or 3:00pm of the working day before the state holiday. The Paid Claim Counts + Closed With No Payment Claim Counts development triangle is equal to the Reported Claim Counts development triangle for this coverage/form/program in the Standard Exhibits Template. Paid Claims + Claims Closed With No Payment should theoretically include only open paid claims, closed paid claims, and claims closed without payment; Reported Claims, however, include the aforementioned claim types as well as open unpaid claims. Therefore, I expect Paid Claim Counts + Closed With No Payment Claim Counts to *not* be a 100% match with Reported Claim Counts. Please correct your data, or provide an explanation.

Objection 1           - New Prior Approval Rate Application (Supporting Document)           Comments: Were there any changes to case reserving practices or mix of business between 2022 and 2023? We noticed the average case reserve increased sharply for the fiscal accident year data ending 2022Q2 to 2023Q2 at the 12-month development. On a slightly related note, your exhibit 7 memorandum says that paid development is less responsive than incurred since it lacks case reserve estimates. What is driving the increase in case reserves in recent periods, and do you expect this to continue? (Please comment also for the period between 2021 and 2022 as well since the case reserves and open claims had a noticeable decrease and then rebounded in 2023.)

Our records indicate that the deemer date for this filing is April 23,2024. In order for us to complete our review, we request a waiver of the deemer. We ask that Allstate Insurance Company submits a SERFF note with the wording below to waive the deemer provisions: Regarding the above-referenced rate application, Allstate Insurance Company ("applicant") hereby waives all deemer provisions of California Insurance Code Section 1861.05, specifically, the 60-day deemer and the 180-day deemer. If the applicant wishes to reactivate the deemer provisions, the applicant will make its request in writing to the Department of Insurance Rate Filing Bureau, Los Angeles, California. Upon reactivation, the 60-day deemer will resume five days after the Department's receipt of the applicant's request to reactivate the deemer, on day 34, and the 180-day deemer will resume five days after the Department's receipt of the applicant's request to reactivate the deemer, on day 57.

Thank you for your recent SERFF submission.  However, it cannot be approved for use in Maine at this time.  Please review and respond to the following objection(s).      Objection 1           Comments: Please be advised that State Farm submitted this filing via the File and Use method on 10/4/2024, per the Companys understanding of Title 24-A, §2304-A. Consistent with the File and Use method and requirements to file not less than 30 days before the effective date in the statute, we processed the revised rates on 12/15/2024 to be available for use for new business on 1/15/2025 and renewal business on 3/15/2025. With our revised rates currently implemented after the 30 days the superintendent has to act, we will continue with our originally communicated effective dates of 1/15/2025 and 3/15/2025, respectively. If the Bureau believes that State Farm has misinterpreted the states filing laws, please provide what authority the Bureau is relying on, and we would be welcome to arrange a call to further discuss your request. The superintendent did act in the form of objections. Maine is a file for approval with a 30 deemer clause not "file and use". Title 24-A, §2304-A. states that filing will be made public once they are approved. Section 5 carves out only specially rate inland marine risks which is not what this filing is. The SERFF rules making this clear are below. Available Filing Modes: Prior Approval  24-A M.R.S. §§ 2304-A and 2412 state that filings are to be made no less than 30 days in advance of their stated effective/delivery date.  Filings may be deemed approved if the filing is not acted upon within 30 days. Acted upon means approved, disapproved, rejected, withdrawn, an objection letter, an extension granted, or there has been a request for additional information Please update this filings effective date so I can approve it.

For the review of the referenced filing we will require answers to the following questions/concerns:      Objection 1           - Exhibit C (Supporting Document)           Comments: Similar to the versions of Exhibit C previously submitted under this filing, the Grand Total proposed dollar effect on Exhibit C should equal the sum of the Total Owners, Total Tenant/Condo, and Total Landlord proposed dollar effects, which is $34,611,800 based on the 1/27/2025 Exhibit C. Please note this represents a 19.7% overall impact based on the $175, 401,093 current written premium as shown on the same Exhibit C. Please confirm if the overall impact is 19.7% or 19.8% and submit an updated Exhibit C that reflects a Grand Total proposed dollar effect that equals the sum of the Total Owners, Total Tenant/Condo, and Total Landlord proposed dollar effects. Also, please submit a Post Submission Update to revise the SERFF Rate/Rule schedule if any information changes.

Objection 1           Comments: As referenced in objection #5 of the 10/11/2024 objection letter, the information on Exhibit B (Exhibit 1 page 1) should be consistent with the information shown on the SERFF Rate/Rule Schedule. Please note the Post Submission Update submitted on 1/6/2025 shows a Written Premium Change of $34,729,416 while the revised Exhibit B shows $34,590,941. Additionally, the overall proposed dollar effect on Exhibit B reflects a +19.7% change when compared to the Current Written Premium on Exhibit B rather than +19.8%. Please either submit a Post Submission Update to amend the Written Premium Change on the SERFF Rate/Rule Schedule or revise the proposed dollar effects on Exhibit B. Also, the proposed dollar effect should be consistent with the overall "proposed % change" given the "current written premium" shown on Exhibit C.

Objection 2           Comments: Exhibit B (Exhibit 1 page 1) shows a -0.1% change for Tenants with a dollar impact of -$4,291. Additionally, while there are 17,812 Tenant policies on Exhibit B, Exhibit 1 page 2 shows 17,644 policies with a 0.0% change, which would indicate at least 168 Tenant policies are receiving a change. However, based on the updated Exhibit 18, there doesn't appear to be any changes to the Tenant rates. As such, please explain why Exhibit B shows a percentage change and dollar impact for Tenants and why the 0.0% on the Unstabilized Impact - Histogram doesn't equal the number of Tenant policies on Exhibit B. What rates are changing with regard to Tenants that would lead to the decrease?
Objection 3           Comments: Please advise as to when you expect the final printed manual pages to be completed.

For the review of the referenced filing we will require answers to the following questions/concerns:      Objection 1           Comments: Please revise the proposal as discussed with the Department. The response should include updates to all impacted exhibits and manual pages, including Exhibits 1 (Histogram) & Exhibit C, as well as a related post submission update to revise the Company Rate Information and to update effective dates.

For the review of the referenced filing we will require answers to the following questions/concerns:      Objection 1           Comments: As previously stated in objection #3 of the 10/11/2024 objection letter, the Department will permit a cap up to 25% to be applied for four annual policy periods. As such, we would like you to be aware that the Rate Stabilization rule can be revised under this filing to 25% as this can help address the company's rate need. If you decide not to update the cap, then please explain why you are choosing to continue using a lower cap than what the Department will permit.

Objection 1           Comments: Please provide the maximum and minimum uncapped combined rate impact for this filing and the previous rate filing approved under SERFF Tracking # TRVD-133948416 (Dept. File #24-0050) as the renewal effective dates for the two filings are within a 12-month period.

Objection 2           Comments: Exhibit 1, pages 2 and 3 are both titled "Unstabilized Impact - Histogram". Please explain the difference between the exhibits. Should Exhibit 1, page 3 have been titled "Stabilized Impact - Histogram"?

Objection 3           Comments: As the maximum rate impact for an individual insured exceeds 25%, a cap not to exceed 25% should be applied per annual policy period in order to limit the sizable rate increases policyholders may see upon renewal as a result of this filing. Please note the cap should apply for four annual policy periods and policyholders must achieve the manually rated premium charge within five years. Please explain how capping will be applied and what, if any, capping rules are currently in effect.

Objection 4           Comments: Related to the previous objection, the Department notes a Rate Stabilization rule was approved under Dept. File #20-2624 and included a Rate Stabilization Table that reflected a 15% cap for 4 years. Is this rule and Rate Stabilization Table still applicable? Were either the rule or table withdrawn under a prior filing? Please note under Dept. File #21-2189, the company responded to our request for capping by stating that "all policyholders affected by this rate change will not have an increase of more than 20% annually". Given the reference to the 20% cap for Dept. File #21-2189, was a new Rate Stabilization Table submitted? Please explain.

Objection 5           Comments: While the current written premium as shown on Exhibit C is consistent with the SERFF Rate/Rule Schedule, the Written Premium Change on the SERFF schedule is not consistent with the proposed dollar effect shown on Exhibit C. As these should be the same, please explain why they are different or submit a Post Submission Update to update the Company Rate Information in SERFF so the premium change is consistent with Exhibit C.

Please explain specifically what is driving the indicated rate need (e.g. type/category of losses, geographic locations, large losses, specific agencies or distribution channels, particular years/periods/events, etc.).  Provide cause of loss distributions or other exhibits demonstrating any changes where appropriate.

Please describe the rationale for the proposed rate filing amount as it relates to the indicated need, as well as the strategic objective(s) with the overall filing (the % increase, other revisions, etc.).

Please provide a discussion of the general type of risk profiles that will receive the larger and smaller premium changes as a result of this filing focusing particularly on the characteristics that are causing the premium changes.  Please do not provide a description of only the individual policies that will receive the maximum and minimum premium change.  Instead provide a description of the general characteristics of the group of policies that will receive the larger and smaller premium changes as well as the basis for targeting such risk types for the related rate changes.
Please summarize other actions being taken by the company, in addition to rate revision filings, to address overall profitability and growth plans, if/as applicable.

Please identify and explain any material increase/decrease in the inforce policy count/exposures over the past several years, identifying the underlying reason(s) and if the directional shift (growing, retracting) is in line with the company objectives in the New Jersey market.

Please define the overall company strategy with writing business in New Jersey as well as what differentiates your product from other competitors in the marketplace such as niche/specialty markets, geographic focus (urban, coastal, etc.), enhanced coverages, preferred/standard/non-standard-type business, multi-line offerings, etc.

Objection 1           Comments: The prior filing increased rates +6.7% based on an indication of +26.0%. This leaves a residual indication of +18.1%. Please reconcile this residual indication with the current indication for this filing of +41.1%.
Objection 2           Comments: Why is Dwelling experience split between non-weather and non-catastrophe-weather, but Landlord Dwelling isn't?
Objection 3           Comments: Please update ULAE data to include data through year-end 2023.

Objection 4           Comments: Please provide Exhibit 14 page 1 of 6 by form. Please confirm our understanding that this data is state-specific data for St. Paul Protective Insurance Company only (rather than Group data).

Objection 5           Comments: Regarding Profit & Contingencies, (1) Please provide updated information that reflects 2023 data. (2) How did you consider the current increased interest rate environment? Please refer to Actuarial Standard of Practice No. 30 Treatment of Profit and Contingency Provisions and the Cost of Capital in Property/Casualty Insurance Ratemaking. Section 3.3 states "Since all components of a rate should be estimates of future costs relating to the risk transfer during the prospective period of time to which the rate applies, capital costs, investment income, income taxes, cash flows, and leverage factors used in calculating the profit provision should be based on expected future values."
No objections

We have the following comments:      Objection 1           - Rates and/or Rating Plans (Supporting Document)           Comments: (a) Regarding the proposed credit of 3%, detailed, comprehensive support must be submitted and reflected on the appropriate exhibits pursuant to the instructions for the Rate Filing Sequence Checklist. The Company states that "The purpose of the Claim Adjustment Fee is to cover Allstate’s loss adjustment expense associated with covered events." Please explain how this does not overlap to the lae adjustment applied for modeled losses.
Please provide 20-30 years of CAT losses for the Company. If the Company has not written for that length of time, please provide the group data instead.

While the Department understands the increase in weather losses over the past ten yeah and that it is reasonable to historically trend weather losses, there is concerns over applying prospective weather trending, Additionally the Company applies a 7% non weather loss trend  historically and prospectively which the Department sees as excessive since the ten year loss ratio for non- weather in the TRD exhibit is 1.4%. Please provide the Department with an alternate indication exhibit that does not trend weather losses prospectively, and uses a 1.4% historical loss trend for non-weather so that the Department may see how sensitive the indication is to changes in these factors. Since this is merely another frame of reference from which to view the filing, the Company is free to comment on why it does not believe this would be appropriate to use or any other such caveats when providing the requested alternate indication,
The Company's underwriting results have been consistently highly favorable in the state even net of reinsurance, which does not appear to support the the proposed rate increase. Please defend.

While there is an indication for the overall change, the support needs to be as granular as the changes themselves. Thus the Company must demonstrate the 13.4% increase in variable package is supported on its own.
Please provide an example calculation to demonstrate how an insured is receiving a 4.7% overall impact.

The Company states that "The purpose of the Claim Adjustment Fee is to cover Allstate’s loss adjustment expense associated with covered events." Please explain how this does not overlap to the lae adjustment applied for modeled losses.

Please provide the Department with an alternate indication exhibit that does not trend weather losses prospectively, and uses a 0.6% historical loss trend for non-weather so that the Department may see how sensitive the indication is to changes in these factors. Please provide an example calculation to demonstrate how an insured is receiving a 7.8% overall impact.
